questions.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions.  Foreigners were assumed to be generally amiable but also intellectually dim and incapable of understanding Chinese social and political conflicts. As such, they were viewed as harmless and therefore to be humored to the extent possible. The father of a friend visiting from America once borrowed my bicycle and blew right past the guards of Zhongnanhai, the compound where China’s top leaders live and work, and rode around, as the guards called to him in Chinese and jogged after the bike. This would be the equivalent of walking into the president’s bedroom in the White House. And while domestic dissidents were treated with great harshness, there was a (i)__________ that attended protection against foreign threats. One time, bicycling, I arrived late to the Great Hall of the People for a meeting with Li Lanqing, the vice premier. I had forgotten to bring the invitation card and my ID. Instead, I showed the guard a CCP membership card I had bought as a novelty at a market. He looked at the card, which I had filled in myself with my atrocious calligraphy, and said, “I didn’t know any foreigners were party members.” I told him, “I’m Number 66,” and he let me in.  Gradually, the membrane between foreign and Chinese thinned and became more porous. There were too many loopholes: Sometimes, Chinese married foreigners, then what were they? Sometimes, people with foreign passports looked Chinese. Sometimes, foreigners had been born in China—should they be restricted?  The government tried to expand the system of controls over foreigners to be less reliant on people and more reliant on technology, such as listening devices and surveillance cameras. But the exceptions started to break that down. Ultimately, the circle of Chinese who participated in foreign privileges got wider and wider, and it became clear that the privileges extended to foreigners would bleed into Chinese life and become a liberalizing influence.  Source: chinafile.com - Keeping the Flies Out - Anne Stevenson-Yang

The father of a friend visiting from America once borrowed my bicycle and blew right past the guards of Zhongnanhai, the compound where China’s top leaders live and work, and rode around, as the guards called to him in Chinese and jogged after the bike. This would be the equivalent of walking into the president’s bedroom in the White House. And while domestic dissidents were treated with great harshness, there was a (i)__________ that attended protection against foreign threats. One time, bicycling, I arrived late to the Great Hall of the People for a meeting with Li Lanqing, the vice premier. I had forgotten to bring the invitation card and my ID. Instead, I showed the guard a CCP membership card I had bought as a novelty at a market. He looked at the card, which I had filled in myself with my atrocious calligraphy, and said, “I didn’t know any foreigners were party members.” I told him, “I’m Number 66,” and he let me in.  Gradually, the membrane between foreign and Chinese thinned and became more porous. There were too many loopholes: Sometimes, Chinese married foreigners, then what were they? Sometimes, people with foreign passports looked Chinese. Sometimes, foreigners had been born in China—should they be restricted?  The government tried to expand the system of controls over foreigners to be less reliant on people and more reliant on technology, such as listening devices and surveillance cameras. But the exceptions started to break that down. Ultimately, the circle of Chinese who participated in foreign privileges got wider and wider, and it became clear that the privileges extended to foreigners would bleed into Chinese life and become a liberalizing influence.  Source: chinafile.com - Keeping the Flies Out - Anne Stevenson-Yang

questions.question_text_1: Read the following exchange between an interviewer and an interviewee and answer the given subquestions:  Ramya: Sir, may I come in?  Interviewer: Yes, please come in.  Ramya: Thank you, sir.  Interviewer: Please have a seat.  (Interviewer reads through her resume)  Interviewer: Hello, Ramya. Please introduce yourself.  Ramya: I am currently working as a Digital Marketing Manager in Wipro. I have about 3 years of experience in this field. Before this, I worked for 2 years as a content editor in Vedantu, which is also an educational company. Coming to my education, I have an MBA in marketing, which I did from Balaji Institute of Modern Management, Pune. I did my BBM from St. Paul’s College in Mangalore. I am currently 33 years old and I live in Bangalore with my husband.  Interviewer: I see. Tell me, why do you want to work with us? It seems like you already have a good job.  Ramya: Yes, sir. I do have a good job, but I am looking for a change in responsibilities. I feel like I have reached my ceiling at my present company. Moreover, it is a wonderful company to work for, but I need more experience and exposure. Hence, I decided to take this step.  Interviewer: Good, that’s good. So tell me why you think you would be a good fit at our company?  Ramya: Sir, I have heard good things about your company in the news lately. Moreover, I believe I have the qualification and experience necessary for this job. However, I would say my biggest driving force to join your organization is my passion for this line of work. In fact, I feel enthusiastic when I do my job.  Interviewer: That sounds fascinating! So what responsibilities did you handle at your company?  Ramya: Since my company was in the education field, we mainly focused on digital marketing – using various tools and techniques to promote our website. You see, our organization makes sales from the leads we generate online. Hence, it is an important responsibility. I also oversaw the daily tasks which were done by my team. I also provide regular reports on the team’s performance and also provide insights if there are any new trends in the world of digital marketing. That way, I can ensure that my team is up-to-date with the current trends and they can plan their work accordingly.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured summary of the **core topics, concepts, and principles** covered in the **English II (Computer-Based Exam)** question paper, along with a **Mermaid knowledge graph** to visualize relationships between key themes.

---

### **Core Topics & Concepts**
The exam tests **four broad areas**:
1. **Reading Comprehension**
2. **Grammar & Syntax**
3. **Vocabulary & Word Formation**
4. **Professional & Social Communication**

---

### **1. Reading Comprehension**
**Key Skills Tested**:
- **Inference**: Drawing conclusions from implicit information (e.g., Q8: Why were foreigners treated less harshly?).
- **Contextual Vocabulary**: Understanding words like *amiable*, *porous*, *novelty*, *atrocious* (Q2, Q4, Q5, Q6).
- **Main Idea & Supporting Details**: Identifying the central theme (e.g., Q7: Loopholes in China’s foreigner control system).
- **Tone & Purpose**: Analyzing authorial intent (e.g., liberalizing influence of foreign privileges in China).

**Passage Themes**:
- **Cultural Perceptions**: Stereotypes about foreigners in China (e.g., "intellectually dim but amiable").
- **Political Control vs. Liberalization**: Shift from human enforcement to technology (surveillance cameras).
- **Identity Ambiguity**: Blurring lines between foreigners and locals (e.g., marriages, passports, birthplace).

---

### **2. Grammar & Syntax**
**Key Concepts**:
#### **A. Tenses**
- **Past Simple** (Q10): *"The father ... **blew** past the guards"* (single completed action).
- **Past Perfect** (Q11): *"I **had forgotten** to bring my ID"* (action completed before another past action).
- **Future Perfect** (Q45): *"They **will have followed**"* (action completed before a future time).

#### **B. Voice (Active/Passive)**
- **Passive to Active** (Q40, Q60):
  - Passive: *"A ticket was booked for me by my father."*
  - Active: *"My father booked a ticket for me."*
- **Conditional Sentences** (Q61):
  - **Third Conditional**: *"If she **had practiced**, she **would have won**."* (hypothetical past).

#### **C. Sentence Structure**
- **Complex Sentences** (Q54): *"Until this roof is repaired, the leak will not stop."* (subordinating conjunction *"until"*).
- **Compound Sentences**: Use of coordinators (*and*, *but*, *or*).
- **Adjuncts** (Q51, Q55): Adverbial phrases modifying verbs (e.g., *"When the president arrived"*, *"following the protests"*).

#### **D. Clauses**
- **Adjectival Clauses** (Q52): *"The movie-adaptation, **which was directed by a famous filmmaker**, became a hit."* (modifies *"movie-adaptation"*).
- **Relative Pronouns** (Q53): *"who"* in *"a man **who** can throw 90 meters."*

#### **E. Question Tags & Intonation**
- **Question Tags** (Q48): *"Something seemed disturbing, **didn’t it?**"* (negative tag for affirmative statements).
- **Intonation** (Q56): Stress on *"they"* in *"Did **they** finish their work?"* (emphasizes the subject).

#### **F. Modals & Deduction**
- **Modals for Deduction** (Q46): *"The exam **must have been** difficult."* (*must* = logical certainty).
- **Future Possibility** (Q47): *"**Will** you finish the book by tomorrow?"*

#### **G. Discourse Markers**
- **Contrast** (Q37, Q57): *"**Although** his despondency made him wish for death, he hesitated."* / *"I could spend this money. **On the other hand**, I could save it."*
- **Opinion** (Q58): *"**Wow**, you look stunning!"* (expresses positive emotion).

---

### **3. Vocabulary & Word Formation**
#### **A. Word Meanings & Synonyms/Antonyms**
| Word       | Meaning/Synonym/Antonym                     | Example Question |
|------------|---------------------------------------------|------------------|
| Amiable    | Friendly (synonym)                          | Q2               |
| Porous     | Impenetrable (antonym)                      | Q4               |
| Novelty    | Cheap little thing                          | Q5               |
| Atrocious  | Horrible (synonym)                          | Q6               |
| Privileges | Benefits (synonym)                          | Q9               |

#### **B. Word Formation Processes**
| Process          | Definition                          | Example          | Question |
|------------------|-------------------------------------|------------------|----------|
| **Blending**     | Combining parts of words.           | *Brexit* (Britain + exit) | Q32      |
| **Compounding**  | Joining two words.                  | *Waterproof* (water + proof) | Q33      |
| **Coinage**      | Inventing new words.                | *Kleenex* (brand name) | Q34      |
| **Borrowing**    | Adopting words from other languages.| *Haiku* (Japanese) | Q35      |
| **Acronymy**     | Using initials as a word.           | *Laser* (Light Amplification...) | Q36      |
| **Clipping**     | Shortening a word.                  | *Blog* (weblog → **fore-clipping**) | Q38      |
| **Back-formation**| Creating a new word by removing affixes. | *Edit* from *editor* | N/A      |

#### **C. Figures of Speech**
- **Metaphor** (Q59): *"All the world’s a stage"* (direct comparison without *like/as*).
- **Other figures** (not tested here): Alliteration, personification, oxymoron.

---

### **4. Professional & Social Communication**
#### **A. Email Writing**
- **Structure**:
  - **Subject Line**: Clear and concise (Q22: *"Textbook Availability Inquiry"*).
  - **Salutation**: Formal (Q23: *"Dear Book Lovers Haven Staff"*).
  - **Body**: Polite and direct (e.g., *"Could you confirm if this book is in stock?"*).
  - **Closing**: Courteous (Q25: *"Thanks in advance for your assistance"*).

#### **B. Interview Skills**
- **Self-Introduction** (Q12–Q21):
  - Highlight **experience** (e.g., *"3 years as a Digital Marketing Manager at Wipro"*).
  - Explain **motivation** (e.g., *"I’ve reached my ceiling and seek new challenges"*).
  - Show **passion** (e.g., *"My biggest driving force is my enthusiasm for this work"*).
- **Responsibilities** (Q16, Q18):
  - Overseeing teams, generating leads, reporting performance.

#### **C. Social Etiquette**
- **Politeness Strategies** (Q27–Q31):
  - **Refusing**: *"This is very kind of you, but I don’t drink coffee."* (Q27).
  - **Requesting**: *"Would you mind taking a look?"* (Q29).
  - **Sensitive Topics**: *"If you’re comfortable, could you share your salary?"* (Q28).

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
#### **Graph 1: Reading Comprehension Themes**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Reading Comprehension] --> B[Cultural Perceptions]
    A --> C[Political Control vs. Liberalization]
    A --> D[Identity Ambiguity]
    B --> E[Stereotypes about Foreigners]
    C --> F[Human Enforcement → Technology]
    C --> G[Privileges for Foreigners]
    D --> H[Marriages/Passports/Birthplace]
```

#### **Graph 2: Grammar & Syntax**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Grammar & Syntax] --> B[Tenses]
    A --> C[Voice]
    A --> D[Sentence Structure]
    A --> E[Clauses]
    A --> F[Question Tags & Intonation]
    A --> G[Modals]
    A --> H[Discourse Markers]
    B --> B1[Past Simple]
    B --> B2[Past Perfect]
    B --> B3[Future Perfect]
    C --> C1[Active/Passive]
    D --> D1[Complex/Compound]
    E --> E1[Adjectival Clauses]
    E --> E2[Relative Pronouns]
    F --> F1[Question Tags]
    F --> F2[Intonation]
    G --> G1[Deduction: must]
    G --> G2[Future: will]
    H --> H1[Contrast: although]
    H --> H2[Opinion: wow]
```

#### **Graph 3: Vocabulary & Word Formation**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Vocabulary] --> B[Synonyms/Antonyms]
    A --> C[Word Formation]
    B --> B1[Amiable = Friendly]
    B --> B2[Porous ≠ Impenetrable]
    C --> C1[Blending: Brexit]
    C --> C2[Compounding: Waterproof]
    C --> C3[Coinage: Kleenex]
    C --> C4[Borrowing: Haiku]
    C --> C5[Acronymy: Laser]
    C --> C6[Clipping: Blog]
```

#### **Graph 4: Professional Communication**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Professional Communication] --> B[Email Writing]
    A --> C[Interview Skills]
    A --> D[Social Etiquette]
    B --> B1[Subject Line]
    B --> B2[Salutation]
    B --> B3[Body]
    B --> B4[Closing]
    C --> C1[Self-Introduction]
    C --> C2[Motivation]
    C --> C3[Responsibilities]
    D --> D1[Polite Refusals]
    D --> D2[Sensitive Requests]
```

---
### **Key Equations/Rules (Grammar)**
1. **Passive Voice Formula**:
   - **Active**: Subject + Verb + Object → **Passive**: Object + *be* + Past Participle + *by* + Subject.
   - Example: *"Amitav Ghosh wrote the novel."* → *"The novel was written by Amitav Ghosh."*

2. **Third Conditional**:
   - *If + Past Perfect, would/could/might + have + Past Participle*.
   - Example: *"If she had practiced, she would have won."*

3. **Question Tags**:
   - **Positive statement** + **negative tag** (e.g., *"She is late, isn’t she?"*).
   - **Negative statement** + **positive tag** (e.g., *"He didn’t come, did he?"*).

4. **Modals for Deduction**:
   - *Must have* (certainty): *"She must have left early."*
   - *Could have* (possibility): *"He could have taken the train."*

5. **Adjectival Clauses**:
   - Introduced by relative pronouns (*who*, *which*, *that*).
   - Example: *"The book **which is on the table** is mine."*
